results.title: The Secondary Teacher
results.creator_credit: E.J. Perry and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Describes the life of secondary student teachers in training: accommodation in a boarding house in Armadale, Victoria, for those from the country areas; Melbourne University and the various courses available for students. Also gives details about specialised couses and shows classes in progress. Shows the science, commerce, music and engineering faculties. Narrated by Terry Dear and animation by the Owen Brothers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: E.J. Perry and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

Also gives details about specialised couses and shows classes in progress. Shows the science, commerce, music and engineering faculties. Narrated by Terry Dear and animation by the Owen Brothers.

results.title: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'
results.brief_description: Jenny He (Curatorial Assistant, Department of Film) and Ron Magliozzi (Assistant Curator, Department of Film) are co-organizers of the Tim Burton exhibition, from MoMa (The Museum of Modern Art) in New York. Here they are interviewed by Kate Warren, ACMI’s Assistant Curator, about their work on ‘Tim Burton: The Exhibition’. They take us through the process, from inception, through to collaborating with Tim Burton, of Burton’s work and the curatorial process. As well as viewing Tim Burton’s work from an artistic perspective, we also gain insight into the art of the curator and curatorial perspective.

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Jason Schleifer
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Jason Schleifer served as Head of Character Animation on DreamWorks Animation’s most recent feature, ‘Mr. Peabody & Sherman’, and has worked on numerous other key titles for the studio including ‘Megamind’, ‘Madagascar’, ‘Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa’, ‘Over the Hedge’ and ‘Shrek the Third’.

Prior to his career at DreamWorks, Schleifer had extensive involvement at Weta Digital, beginning as a Creature Technical Director and later promoted to an Animation Lead while making the ‘Lord of the Rings’ Trilogy.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film showcases Papua New Guinea (PNG) in the 1960s. It begins with coastal towns and ports, sighing, canoes and boats and then travels by plane to the ‘Highlands’ on what appears to be a cargo plane. Along the way, Wallace captures the villages, the dramatic landscapes and the various peoples of PNG.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a group of smiling children walk along a road under palm trees
00:00:25:00 thatched houses facing a lagoon
00:01:45:00 taking down the sail on a local ‘outrigger canoe’
00:02:18:00 view from a plane overhead and a TAA (Trans Australia Airlines) plane on an airfield being emptied of cargo
00:02:32:00 several totem sculptures and carved statues
00:02:57:00 a man spearing fish in the waves off a rocky perch
00:03:09:00 Coastwatchers Memorial in Madang
00:03:18:00 ‘Petrus II’ sailing boat and unloading cargo of cacao beans in large hessian sacks from a boat onto a pier
00:03:54:00 a lovely old rusty shed, jetty and boats in a palm tree setting
00:04:04:00 school girls playing sport
00:04:29:00 fixing a car in a village of thatch covered houses
00:05:04:00 canoes being paddled across the water
00:06:07:00 a larger boat followed by scenes around a portside town
00:07:34:00 a particularly picturesque roadside store, Central Merchants, and people carrying goods on shoulders and heads
00:08:34:00 ‘44 gallon drums’ being unloaded from a plane by being bounced onto a large rubber tyre
00:08:54:00 aeriel views over the jungles and mountains and misty clouds
00:09:24:00 a long winding river being filmed from the plane above
00:11:29:00 boarding a TAA plane and takeoff with the mountains in the background
00:12:04:00 a small yellow plane
00:12:08:00 a village with thatched houses
00:12:50:00 small planes
00:13:00:00 traditional dress
00:13:23:00 flying over mountains and looking at roads criss-crossing the terrain
00:19:38:00 traditional grass mat weaving
00:21:53:00 sign ‘Kainantu Mile High Gateway to the Highlands Alt. 5280’
00:22:21:00 a large river system from overhead
00:22:10:00 a signpost for ‘Mumeng’, ‘Bulolo’ and ‘Wau’
00:23:38:00 lush valleys in the Highlands
00:25:44:00 sign ‘You are now approaching Wau, Top of Drome, Elvn 3200’
00:28:58:00 house in the trees
00:29:11:00 people washing clothes in the river
00:30:10:00 a cemetery and white crucifix monuments
00:31:04:00 TAA plane

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: The Ties that bind
results.creator_credit: Milad Bardan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It took seven years after the death of his mother and a political assassination in his birth country of Lebanon before Milad really got to know his father. This is a tribute to that man.

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip to Papua New Guinea in 1961. The filmmaker captures a seaside town, fishing boats, people at a market and men in traditional headdresses, as well as the Boumana (Bomana) War Cemetery in Port Moresby.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:27:00 fishing boats by the sea
00:02:05:00 group of women sitting around talking
00:03:19:00 young child
00:04:21:00 boats in the bay
00:05:21:00 sign for ‘Boumana War Cemetery’
00:06:45:00 views across a valley
00:07:04:00 a waterfall
00:09:05:00 men in headdresses
00:09:16:00 a polo game with locals watching
00:10:57:00 views over the bay
00:12:44:00 girls playing a ball game
00:13:15:00 man fixing a small boat
00:14:00:00 a traffic warden in the middle of an intersection
00:15:16:00 views from an aeroplane

results.title: Frontline
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, Australian War Memorial, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, British Broadcasting Corporation and ABC
results.brief_description:
An account of the Vietnam War as seen through the camera of the late Australian war correspondent, Neil Davis. David Bradbury’s multi-award winning documentary also examines the ethical issues facing a man in the frontline who is not an active combatant.
Vietnam was a television war, a war said to have been lost in the lounge rooms of middle America, and not on the battlefield. This film explores the conflict, and Davis’ involvement in it, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. It includes the famous, historic footage of the fall of Saigon, which Davis was the only Western journalist to film.

Warning: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Romance calling: the forgotten city
results.brief_description: Film tells of the discovery of Angkor Thom, “the forbidden city” in Indo China and of its previous civilisation, showing ruins of this now extinct city.
